description: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest. [from HPO]
A sensation of lightheadedness, unsteadiness, turning, spinning or rocking. [from NCI]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]
A sudden movement downward, usually resulting in injury. [from NCI]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary. [from HPO]
A watery secretion by the sweat glands that is primarily composed of salt, urea and minerals. [from NCI]
Profuse sweating. [from NCI]
A sensation that the heart is pounding or racing, which is a non-specific sign but may be a manifestation of arrhythmia. [from HPO]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]
Paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. source_name: Diagnosis and treatment of acute bronchitis.

description: A cough that does not produce phlegm or mucus. [from HPO]
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing. [from HPO]
Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs. [from HPO]

Respiratory distress is objectively observable as the physical or emotional consequences from the experience of dyspnea. The physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing, while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea. [from HPO]
Very rapid breathing. [from HPO]
A feeling of general discomfort, weakness, or lack of health. [from HPO]
A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing. [from HPO]

Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed. [from HPO]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]
Abnormal coordination of muscles involved in speech. [from HPO]
Reduced strength of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve). [from HPO]
Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body. [from HPO]

description: A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. [from HPO]

An unpleasant sensation of tightness or pressure in the chest. [from HPO]
A cough that does not produce phlegm or mucus. [from HPO]
Pleuritic chest pain is characterized by sudden and intense sharp, stabbing, or burning pain in the chest when inhaling and exhaling. [from HPO]
A cough that produces phlegm or mucus. [from HPO]
An aggravating factor is defined as an external factor that leads to a sign or symptom that is already present getting worse or becoming more severe. [from HPO]

Respiratory distress is objectively observable as the physical or emotional consequences from the experience of dyspnea. The physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing, while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest. [from HPO]
An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located superior to the isoelectric line. [from HPO]

Profuse sweating. [from NCI]
An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located inferior to the isoelectric line. [from HPO]

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]
Paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia. [from HPO]

description: A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute). [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]

description: Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
A loss of the sensation of feeling in an area of the body. [from NCI]

description: An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located inferior to the isoelectric line. [from HPO]
Mental distress resulting from concern for something impending or anticipated. [from NCI]
An inversion of the T-wave (which is normally positive). [from HPO]
A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute). [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin. [from HPO]
The quality of being opaque to a degree; the degree to which something reduces the passage of light. [from NCI]
Simultaneous enlargement of the liver and spleen. [from HPO]
A sudden sensation of feeling cold. [from HPO]
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus. [from HPO]
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements. [from HPO]

An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]

description: A state of disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating. [from HPO]
A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension. [from HPO]
A purpuric lesion that is larger than 1 cm in diameter. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
An inability to purposefully respond to stimuli. [from NCI]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]

description: Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation [from NCI]

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]

A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. [from HPO]
Lack of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination at an age where control of the bladder should already be possible. [from HPO]
A state of disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating. [from HPO]
Abnormal coordination of muscles involved in speech. [from HPO]
A sudden movement downward, usually resulting in injury. [from NCI]
An alteration in the mental status of an individual. [from NCI]
A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints. [from HPO]
An inability to purposefully respond to stimuli. [from NCI]
A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension. [from HPO]
The occurrence of a single contraction or a series of contractions of a muscle. [from NCI]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]
A sensation of lightheadedness, unsteadiness, turning, spinning or rocking. [from NCI]
Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve. [from HPO]

Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed. [from HPO]
A feeling of faintness; a reeling sensation. Lightheadedness is medically distinct from dizziness, unsteadiness, and vertigo. [from NCI]
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement about a joint axis. [from HPO]
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the blood. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
A disturbing dream that occurs during rapid eye movement sleep and results in feelings of strong terror, fear, distress, or anxiety. [from NCI]

Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist. [from HPO]

A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute). [from HPO]
A position of the fetus at delivery in which the fetus enters the birth canal with the buttocks or feet first. [from HPO]
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucosa due to poor circulation or inadequate oxygenation of arterial or capillary blood. [from HPO]
A rupture of the fetal membranes that is not concurrent with or immediately following a digital exam or other transvaginal intervention involving the amniotic membrane. [from NCI]
The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel. [from NCI]

Increased size of the heart, clinically defined as an increased transverse diameter of the cardiac silhouette that is greater than or equal to 50% of the transverse diameter of the chest (increased cardiothoracic ratio) on a posterior-anterior projection of a chest radiograph or a computed tomography. Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin. [from HPO]
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension. [from HPO]
A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch. [from HPO]
A cough that does not produce phlegm or mucus. [from HPO]

description: Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
A state of disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating. [from HPO]
A sensation of lightheadedness, unsteadiness, turning, spinning or rocking. [from NCI]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes. [from NCI]
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part. [from NCI]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest. [from HPO]
The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine). [from HPO]

The local spread of tumor cells of a malignant neoplasm through infiltration or destruction of adjacent tissue; for epithelial neoplasms, invasion signifies infiltration beneath the epithelial basement membrane. [from NCI]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]

An inability to perceive odors. This is a general term describing inability to smell arising in any part of the process of smelling from absorption of odorants into the nasal mucous overlying the olfactory epithelium, diffusion to the cilia, binding to olfactory receptor sites, generation of action potentials in olfactory neurons, and perception of a smell. [from HPO]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
A tumor arising at a location distant to the primary lesion. [from NCI]

A detrimental reaction to a food, beverage, food additive, or compound found in foods that produces symptoms in one or more body organs and systems that is not mediated by an immune reaction. [from HPO]

description: A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing. [from HPO]

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]
A sensation that the heart is pounding or racing, which is a non-specific sign but may be a manifestation of arrhythmia. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]

description: Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [from HPO]
Increase in size of the left atrium. [from HPO]

Abnormally increased body weight. [from HPO]
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]
A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing. [from HPO]

Low output of urine, clinically classified as an output below 300-500ml/day. [from HPO]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]
An alteration in the mental status of an individual. [from NCI]
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements. [from HPO]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation of tightness or pressure in the chest. [from HPO]
A feeling of general discomfort, weakness, or lack of health. [from HPO]
A sudden sensation of feeling cold. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
Pleuritic chest pain is characterized by sudden and intense sharp, stabbing, or burning pain in the chest when inhaling and exhaling. [from HPO]

description: Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation [from NCI]

A neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by one or more of the following essential features: immobility, mutism, negativism (active or passive refusal to follow commands), mannerisms, stereotypies, posturing, grimacing, excitement, echolalia, echopraxia, muscular rigidity, and stupor; sometimes punctuated by sudden violent outbursts, panic, or hallucinations. This condition may be associated with psychiatric illnesses (e.g., SCHIZOPHRENIA; MOOD DISORDERS) or organic disorders (NEUROLEPTIC MALIGNANT SYNDROME; ENCEPHALITIS, etc.). (From DSM-IV, 4th ed, 1994; APA, Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms, 1994) [from MeSH]

description: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes. [from NCI]

A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part. [from NCI]

The local spread of tumor cells of a malignant neoplasm through infiltration or destruction of adjacent tissue; for epithelial neoplasms, invasion signifies infiltration beneath the epithelial basement membrane. [from NCI]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
Hoarseness refers to a change in the pitch or quality of the voice, with the voice sounding weak, very breathy, scratchy, or husky. [from HPO]
A tumor arising at a location distant to the primary lesion. [from NCI]
A cough that does not produce phlegm or mucus. [from HPO]
Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces. [from HPO]
Abnormal sensations such as tingling, pricking, or numbness of the skin with no apparent physical cause. [from HPO]

description: A feeling of sadness characterized by crying episodes that can come on suddenly and are not under usual social control. [from HPO]
Hyperactivity is a state of constantly being unusually or abnormally active, including in situations in which it is not appropriate. [from HPO]

A neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by one or more of the following essential features: immobility, mutism, negativism (active or passive refusal to follow commands), mannerisms, stereotypies, posturing, grimacing, excitement, echolalia, echopraxia, muscular rigidity, and stupor; sometimes punctuated by sudden violent outbursts, panic, or hallucinations. This condition may be associated with psychiatric illnesses (e.g., SCHIZOPHRENIA; MOOD DISORDERS) or organic disorders (NEUROLEPTIC MALIGNANT SYNDROME; ENCEPHALITIS, etc.). (From DSM-IV, 4th ed, 1994; APA, Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms, 1994) [from MeSH]
Mental distress resulting from concern for something impending or anticipated. [from NCI]
Persistent difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep. [from HPO]
A sleep disorder characterized by excessive sleepiness. [from NCI]
Something not easily done, accomplished, comprehended, or solved. [from NCI]
Visual perceptions that are not elicited by a corresponding stimulus from the outside world. [from HPO]
Abnormal excessive perspiration (sweating) despite the lack of appropriate stimuli like hot and humid weather. [from HPO]
Abnormal dilatation of the iris. [from HPO]

A neurological condition related to lesions of the basal ganglia leading to typical abnormalities including akinesia (inability to initiate changes in activity and perform volitional movements rapidly and easily), muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement), chorea (widespread arrhythmic movements of a forcible, rapid, jerky, and restless nature), athetosis (inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, or other group of muscles in a fixed position), and akathisia (inability to remain motionless). [from HPO]
Diminished control of mental or physical functioning caused by a substance. [from SNOMEDCT_US]

description: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]

A neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by one or more of the following essential features: immobility, mutism, negativism (active or passive refusal to follow commands), mannerisms, stereotypies, posturing, grimacing, excitement, echolalia, echopraxia, muscular rigidity, and stupor; sometimes punctuated by sudden violent outbursts, panic, or hallucinations. This condition may be associated with psychiatric illnesses (e.g., SCHIZOPHRENIA; MOOD DISORDERS) or organic disorders (NEUROLEPTIC MALIGNANT SYNDROME; ENCEPHALITIS, etc.). (From DSM-IV, 4th ed, 1994; APA, Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms, 1994) [from MeSH]

Deep, noisy breathing during sleep accompanied by hoarse or harsh sounds caused by the vibration of respiratory structures (especially the soft palate) resulting in sound due to obstructed air movement during breathing while sleeping. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest. [from HPO]

description: Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
An electrocardiographic finding of an atrial rhythm which originates from the sinoatrial node that is considered normal for the population. (CDISC) [from NCI]
A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute). [from HPO]
A watery secretion by the sweat glands that is primarily composed of salt, urea and minerals. [from NCI]
Profuse sweating. [from NCI]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
Without clinical signs or indications that raise the possibility of a particular disorder or dysfunction. [from NCI]
A lack or loss of appetite for food (as a medical condition). [from HPO]
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. [from HPO]
A sudden movement downward, usually resulting in injury. [from NCI]
Abnormal increased size of the spleen. [from HPO]
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]

The local spread of tumor cells of a malignant neoplasm through infiltration or destruction of adjacent tissue; for epithelial neoplasms, invasion signifies infiltration beneath the epithelial basement membrane. [from NCI]
Distention of the abdomen. [from HPO]
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part. [from NCI]

description: Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [from HPO]
Without clinical signs or indications that raise the possibility of a particular disorder or dysfunction. [from NCI]

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
Increase in size of the left atrium. [from HPO]
A sensation that the heart is pounding or racing, which is a non-specific sign but may be a manifestation of arrhythmia. [from HPO]
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation. [from HPO]
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]

Increased size of the heart, clinically defined as an increased transverse diameter of the cardiac silhouette that is greater than or equal to 50% of the transverse diameter of the chest (increased cardiothoracic ratio) on a posterior-anterior projection of a chest radiograph or a computed tomography. description: Persistent difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep. [from HPO]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]

description: Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
A sudden sensation of feeling cold. [from HPO]
Stridor is a high pitched sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the upper airway. [from HPO]

Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed. [from HPO]
A slight or incomplete paralysis. [from NCI]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]
The inability or refusal to swallow. [from NCI]

A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. [from HPO]
Abnormal coordination of muscles involved in speech. [from HPO]

A focal-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating within networks limited to one hemisphere. They may be discretely localized or more widely distributed, and may originate in subcortical structures. [from HPO]
Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body. [from HPO]

description: A state of reduced sensibility and response to stimuli which is distinguished from COMA in that the person can be aroused by vigorous and repeated stimulation. The person is still conscious and can make voluntary movements. It can be induced by CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM AGENTS. The word derives from Latin stupere and is related to stunned, stupid, dazed or LETHARGY. [from MeSH]

description: Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Motor paralysis results from deficits of the upper motor neurons (corticospinal, corticobulbar, or subcorticospinal). Motor paralysis is often accompanied by an impairment in the facility of movement. [from HPO]
A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch. [from HPO]
Reduced strength of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve). [from HPO]
Lower urinary tract symptom, such as slow urinary stream, associated with PROSTATIC HYPERPLASIA in older men. [from MeSH]
A sudden movement downward, usually resulting in injury. [from NCI]
Abnormally increased hair growth referring to a male pattern of body hair (androgenic hair). [from HPO]

description: Bradykinesia literally means slow movement, and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement (in contrast to hypokinesia, which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement). [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]

description: Involuntary discharge of URINE that is associated with an abrupt and strong desire to void. It is usually related to the involuntary contractions of the detrusor muscle of the bladder (detrusor hyperreflexia or detrusor instability). [from MeSH]

Reduced strength of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve). [from HPO]

A sensation of tightness in the neck when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. Neck stiffness often involves soreness and difficulty moving the neck, especially when trying to turn the head to the side. [from HPO]
An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary. [from HPO]
A loss of the sensation of feeling in an area of the body. [from NCI]
A feeling of faintness; a reeling sensation. Lightheadedness is medically distinct from dizziness, unsteadiness, and vertigo. [from NCI]

A neurological condition related to lesions of the basal ganglia leading to typical abnormalities including akinesia (inability to initiate changes in activity and perform volitional movements rapidly and easily), muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement), chorea (widespread arrhythmic movements of a forcible, rapid, jerky, and restless nature), athetosis (inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, or other group of muscles in a fixed position), and akathisia (inability to remain motionless). description: Lack of sharpness of vision resulting in the inability to see fine detail. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
Something not easily done, accomplished, comprehended, or solved. [from NCI]

description: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement about a joint axis. [from HPO]
Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
A sudden movement downward, usually resulting in injury. [from NCI]

description: A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing. [from HPO]
Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest. [from HPO]
A sensation that the heart is pounding or racing, which is a non-specific sign but may be a manifestation of arrhythmia. [from HPO]
A watery secretion by the sweat glands that is primarily composed of salt, urea and minerals. [from NCI]
Profuse sweating. [from NCI]
Abnormally increased body weight. [from HPO]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]

Hyperventilation refers to an increased pulmonary ventilation rate that is faster than necessary for the exchange of gases. Hyperventilation can result from increased frequency of breathing, an increased tidal volume, or both, and leads to an excess intake of oxygen and the blowing off of carbon dioxide. [from HPO]

description: A detrimental reaction to a food, beverage, food additive, or compound found in foods that produces symptoms in one or more body organs and systems that is not mediated by an immune reaction. [from HPO]
The pulsation of an artery where the pulse is taken (e.g. the radial artery at the wrist) cannot be detected on physical examination. [from HPO]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes. [from NCI]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine). [from HPO]

Painful sensations elicited by a nonpainful cutaneous stimulus such as a light touch or gentle stroking over affected areas of the body. Sometimes referred to as hyperpathia or hyperalgesia. Often perceived as an intense burning, dyesthesias may outlast the stimulus by several seconds. [from HPO]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]

description: Pleuritic chest pain is characterized by sudden and intense sharp, stabbing, or burning pain in the chest when inhaling and exhaling. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. description: Involuntary discharge of URINE that is associated with an abrupt and strong desire to void. It is usually related to the involuntary contractions of the detrusor muscle of the bladder (detrusor hyperreflexia or detrusor instability). [from MeSH]
Painful or difficult urination. [from HPO]
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements. [from HPO]
An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary. [from HPO]
Increased time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG). [from HPO]

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts. [from HPO]
A slight or incomplete paralysis. [from NCI]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
Very rapid breathing. [from HPO]
A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing. [from HPO]

Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
A watery secretion by the sweat glands that is primarily composed of salt, urea and minerals. [from NCI]
Profuse sweating. [from NCI]

description: Abnormally increased size of the liver. [from HPO]
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation. [from HPO]
Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [from HPO]

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]

description: Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
Urge incontinence is the strong, sudden need to urinate. [from HPO]
A lack or loss of appetite for food (as a medical condition). [from HPO]
Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
An abnormally increased potassium concentration in the blood. [from HPO]
A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing. [from HPO]
Excessive daytime sleepiness. [from HPO]
Abnormally increased body weight. [from HPO]
An abnormally decreased potassium concentration in the blood. [from HPO]
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension. [from HPO]
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation [from NCI]
Distention of the abdomen. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]
Weakness or partial paralysis in the lower limbs. [from HPO]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]

description: Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve. [from HPO]
A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing. [from HPO]
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation. [from HPO]
Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
A heart murmur that occurs during the entire systolic phase from S1 to S2. [from HPO]

A heart murmur that occurs predominantly in midsystole, when ejection volume and velocity of blood flow are at their maximum; it is produced by ejection of blood into the pulmonary artery and aorta. It is typically crescendo-decrescendo. [from NCI]
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension. [from HPO]
Paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia. [from HPO]

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]
Any kind of inflammatory process of the tonsils, pharynx, or/and larynx characterized by pain in swallowing. [from NCI]
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing. [from HPO]
Breathing that requires observed effort or an increased amount of energy. [from NCI]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
A cough that does not produce phlegm or mucus. [from HPO]
Increased discharge of mucus from the nose. [from HPO]
An emotional state of indifference characterized by a lack of interest or concern. [from NCI]

description: A sensation of tightness in the neck when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. Neck stiffness often involves soreness and difficulty moving the neck, especially when trying to turn the head to the side. [from HPO]
Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [from HPO]
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucosa due to poor circulation or inadequate oxygenation of arterial or capillary blood. [from HPO]
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension. [from HPO]
Increase in size of the left atrium. [from HPO]
Abnormal sensations such as tingling, pricking, or numbness of the skin with no apparent physical cause. [from HPO]
Nodding movement of the head or body. [from HPO]

Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed. [from HPO]
Pain experienced with swallowing. [from HPO]
Hoarseness refers to a change in the pitch or quality of the voice, with the voice sounding weak, very breathy, scratchy, or husky. [from HPO]
Stridor is a high pitched sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the upper airway. [from HPO]
Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles. [from HPO]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as pronating and supinating his or her hand on the dorsum of the other hand as rapidly as possible. [from HPO]

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts. [from HPO]

A dull achy pain. [from NCI]

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. [from HPO]
A purpuric lesion that is larger than 1 cm in diameter. [from HPO]
An increased number of circulating monocytes. [from HPO]
Excessive mucous secretion in the back of the nasal cavity or throat, causing sore throat and/or coughing. It is usually due to allergic rhinitis or a cold. [from NCI]
The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel. [from NCI]
Very rapid breathing. [from HPO]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus. [from HPO]
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension. [from HPO]
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation. [from HPO]

description: Extreme fatigue; inability to respond to stimuli. [from NCI]

A state of reduced sensibility and response to stimuli which is distinguished from COMA in that the person can be aroused by vigorous and repeated stimulation. The person is still conscious and can make voluntary movements. It can be induced by CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM AGENTS. The word derives from Latin stupere and is related to stunned, stupid, dazed or LETHARGY. [from MeSH]

A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. [from HPO]
Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body. [from HPO]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]

description: Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]

Nausea is a commonly encountered symptom that has been defined as an unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit. Vomiting has been defined as the forceful expulsion of the contents of the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum through the oral cavity. While nausea and vomiting are often thought to exist on a temporal continuum, this is not always the case. There are situations when severe nausea may be present without emesis and less frequently, when emesis may be present without preceding nausea. [from HPO]
A type of insomnia characterized by waking up (too) early in the morning. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]
A sudden sensation of feeling cold. [from HPO]
A repeated, painful urge to defecate without excreting stool. [from HPO]

Involuntary discharge of URINE that is associated with an abrupt and strong desire to void. It is usually related to the involuntary contractions of the detrusor muscle of the bladder (detrusor hyperreflexia or detrusor instability). [from MeSH]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]

description: Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow. [from HPO]
Reduced strength of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve). [from HPO]

description: Mental distress resulting from concern for something impending or anticipated. [from NCI]
Excessive daytime sleepiness. [from HPO]
The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine). [from HPO]
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement about a joint axis. [from HPO]
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes. [from NCI]
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part. [from NCI]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]

A smooth, slightly elevated area on the body surface, which is redder or paler than the surrounding skin. It is the typical lesion of urticaria, the dermal evidence of allergy, and in sensitive persons may be provoked by mechanical irritation of the skin. [from NCI]

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts. [from HPO]
Tinnitus is an auditory perception that can be described as the experience of sound, in the ear or in the head, in the absence of external acoustic stimulation. [from HPO]
A collection of fluid and gas within the pleural cavity. (Dorland, 27th ed) [from MeSH]

description: Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs. [from HPO]
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation. [from HPO]
Excessive thirst manifested by excessive fluid intake. [from HPO]
A dull achy pain. [from NCI]
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus. [from HPO]
A small elevation of the skin containing cloudy or purulent material usually consisting of necrotic inflammatory cells. [from HPO]
A rounded, puffy face with fat deposits in the temporal fossa and cheeks, a double chin. [from HPO]
An emotional state characterized by feelings of sadness, emptiness, and/or tearfulness. [from NCI]
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing. [from HPO]
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. [from HPO]

A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. [from HPO]
A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints. [from HPO]
The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel. [from NCI]
Excessive daytime sleepiness. [from HPO]

description: An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]
A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute). [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]

The formation of fibrous tissue in the place of normal tissue during the process of WOUND HEALING. It includes scar tissue formation occurring in healing internal organs as well as in the skin after surface injuries. [from MeSH]
Displacement of structures in the thoracic cavity in one direction due to increased pleural pressure on the contralateral side. [from NCI]
Abnormal cognition with deficits in thinking, reasoning, or remembering. [from HPO]
Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth. [from HPO]
A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension. [from HPO]
A disturbing dream that occurs during rapid eye movement sleep and results in feelings of strong terror, fear, distress, or anxiety. [from NCI]
Abnormal breath sounds characterized by low-pitched, snoring or rattle-like sounds. [from HPO]

Any noxious and unintended response(s) to a medical product or procedure, for which a causal relationship with this product or procedure is at least a reasonable possibility i.e., the relationship cannot be ruled out. [from NCI]

The term was used in various ways in the past, to describe unintended effects of medical intervention, usually negative (unfavourable), but also positive (favourable) ones. It is recommended that this term no longer be used and particularly should not be regarded as synonymous with adverse event or adverse reaction. [from NCI]
Distention of the abdomen associated with a feeling of fullness. [from NCI]
A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body. [from HPO]
A loss of the sensation of feeling in an area of the body. [from NCI]

Nausea is a commonly encountered symptom that has been defined as an unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit. Vomiting has been defined as the forceful expulsion of the contents of the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum through the oral cavity. While nausea and vomiting are often thought to exist on a temporal continuum, this is not always the case. There are situations when severe nausea may be present without emesis and less frequently, when emesis may be present without preceding nausea. [from HPO]
A type of insomnia characterized by waking up (too) early in the morning. [from HPO]
A collection of fluid and gas within the pleural cavity. (Dorland, 27th ed) [from MeSH]

description: The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel. [from NCI]
The unintentional or intentional loss of a pregnancy before 22 weeks gestation. [from NCI]
Prolonged/excessive menses and bleeding at irregular intervals. [from HPO]

Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist. [from HPO]

description: An intense sensation of discomfort or distress that radiates from one location to another sharply. [from NCI]
A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute). [from HPO]
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]

A heart murmur that occurs predominantly in midsystole, when ejection volume and velocity of blood flow are at their maximum; it is produced by ejection of blood into the pulmonary artery and aorta. It is typically crescendo-decrescendo. [from NCI]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]

description: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes. [from NCI]
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part. [from NCI]
Abdominal discomfort with retrosternal pain usually associated with gastroesophageal reflux.. [from NCI]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
A sudden sensation of feeling cold. [from HPO]
The quality of being opaque to a degree; the degree to which something reduces the passage of light. [from NCI]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]

A detrimental reaction to a food, beverage, food additive, or compound found in foods that produces symptoms in one or more body organs and systems that is not mediated by an immune reaction. [from HPO]

Respiratory distress is objectively observable as the physical or emotional consequences from the experience of dyspnea. The physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing, while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea. [from HPO]
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension. [from HPO]
Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body. [from HPO]

Deep, noisy breathing during sleep accompanied by hoarse or harsh sounds caused by the vibration of respiratory structures (especially the soft palate) resulting in sound due to obstructed air movement during breathing while sleeping. [from HPO]

description: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus. [from HPO]
A breast lump is any discrete mass in a breast noticed by the patient, significant other, or physician. [from HPO]
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]

The diagnosis of severe breath-holding spells (BHS) in childhood is based on a distinctive and stereotyped sequence of clinical events beginning with a provocation resulting in crying or emotional upset that leads to a noiseless state of expiration accompanied by color change and ultimately loss of consciousness and postural tone (Lombroso and Lerman, 1967; DiMario, 1992). Two clinical types are recognized based on the child's coloration (cyanotic or pallid) during these events. Most children experience the cyanotic type, although some experience mixed types. BHS is an involuntary, nonvolitional, reflexic, nonepileptic paroxysmal phenomenon of childhood. The episodes occur during full expiration despite its misnomer. Autonomic dysregulation has been hypothesized as an underlying mechanism that results in loss of consciousness (Hunt, 1990; DiMario and Burleson, 1993; Dimario et al., 1998). [from OMIM]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]
A dull achy pain. [from NCI]
Conjunctival icterus is a condition where there is yellowing of the whites of the eyes. This is most commonly seen in patients who have liver disease. [from HPO]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
Pain in muscle. [from HPO]
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the blood. [from HPO]
Involuntary spasms of the stomach and esophagus resulting in vomiting or dry heaving. [from NCI]
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes. [from NCI]
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part. [from NCI]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]
Focal rounded or ovoid opacity, not more than 3 cm in diameter. Pulmonary nodules are typically observed by chest radiography or computer tomography imaging. [from HPO]
Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs. [from HPO]

description: Frequent thinking about or preoccupation with killing oneself. [from HPO]
A disturbing dream that occurs during rapid eye movement sleep and results in feelings of strong terror, fear, distress, or anxiety. [from NCI]
A person who was assigned to one gender at birth based on physical characteristics but who self-identifies psychologically and emotionally as the other. [from NCI]
The false perception of sound. [from HPO]
Excited response to stimuli. [from NCI]
Persistent difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep. [from HPO]
A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension. [from HPO]
A feeling of sadness characterized by crying episodes that can come on suddenly and are not under usual social control. [from HPO]
An emotional state characterized by feelings of sadness, emptiness, and/or tearfulness. [from NCI]

Nausea is a commonly encountered symptom that has been defined as an unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit. Vomiting has been defined as the forceful expulsion of the contents of the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum through the oral cavity. While nausea and vomiting are often thought to exist on a temporal continuum, this is not always the case. There are situations when severe nausea may be present without emesis and less frequently, when emesis may be present without preceding nausea. [from HPO]
Extreme fatigue; inability to respond to stimuli. [from NCI]
Mental distress resulting from concern for something impending or anticipated. [from NCI]
Lack of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination at an age where control of the bladder should already be possible. [from HPO]
Without a stable or permanent residence. [from NCI]
An uneasy psychological state; the anxious feeling you have when you have the jitters. [from NCI]
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. [from HPO]
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus. [from HPO]
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes. [from NCI]
Abnormal increased size of the spleen. [from HPO]
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part. [from NCI]
A slight or incomplete paralysis. [from NCI]

The local spread of tumor cells of a malignant neoplasm through infiltration or destruction of adjacent tissue; for epithelial neoplasms, invasion signifies infiltration beneath the epithelial basement membrane. [from NCI]
The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel. [from NCI]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
An emotional state of indifference characterized by a lack of interest or concern. [from NCI]
Severe weight loss, wasting of muscle, loss of appetite, and general debility related to a chronic disease. [from HPO]
Reduced body temperature due to failed thermoregulation. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]
Abnormally increased size of the liver. [from HPO]
A reduction below the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood. [from HPO]

A state of reduced sensibility and response to stimuli which is distinguished from COMA in that the person can be aroused by vigorous and repeated stimulation. The person is still conscious and can make voluntary movements. It can be induced by CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM AGENTS. The word derives from Latin stupere and is related to stunned, stupid, dazed or LETHARGY. [from MeSH]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]

description: Severe weight loss, wasting of muscle, loss of appetite, and general debility related to a chronic disease. [from HPO]
An aggravating factor is defined as an external factor that leads to a sign or symptom that is already present getting worse or becoming more severe. [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]

Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position. [from HPO]
Recurrent episodes of redness of the skin together with a sensation of warmth or burning of the affected areas of skin. [from HPO]
Pain experienced with swallowing. [from HPO]
Joint pain. [from HPO]
Interference with respiration by compression or obstruction of the larynx or trachea. [from NCI]
A repeated, painful urge to defecate without excreting stool. [from HPO]
Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces. [from HPO]
The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel. [from NCI]
An decreased amount of bowel sounds. [from HPO]

description: Nausea is a commonly encountered symptom that has been defined as an unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit. Vomiting has been defined as the forceful expulsion of the contents of the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum through the oral cavity. While nausea and vomiting are often thought to exist on a temporal continuum, this is not always the case. There are situations when severe nausea may be present without emesis and less frequently, when emesis may be present without preceding nausea. [from HPO]
The desire for FOOD generated by a sensation arising from the lack of food in the STOMACH. [from MeSH]
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements. [from HPO]
A sensation of lightheadedness, unsteadiness, turning, spinning or rocking. [from NCI]
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the blood. [from HPO]
A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]
A sensation of stinging or heat, not necessarily accompanied by redness or physical signs of irritation. [from NCI]

description: Reduced strength of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve). [from HPO]
The inability or refusal to swallow. [from NCI]
The occurrence of a single contraction or a series of contractions of a muscle. [from NCI]

Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Motor paralysis results from deficits of the upper motor neurons (corticospinal, corticobulbar, or subcorticospinal). Motor paralysis is often accompanied by an impairment in the facility of movement. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the lower back. [from HPO]
Paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia. [from HPO]
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. [from HPO]
Breathing that requires observed effort or an increased amount of energy. [from NCI]
Reduced body temperature due to failed thermoregulation. [from HPO]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]
A reduction below the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood. [from HPO]
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing. [from HPO]
An abnormally low level of blood oxygen. [from HPO]

description: Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage. [from HPO]
Urge incontinence is the strong, sudden need to urinate. [from HPO]
The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine). [from HPO]
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions. [from HPO]
A sudden sensation of feeling cold. [from HPO]
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements. [from HPO]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [from HPO]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen. [from HPO]
Pain in muscle. [from HPO]
Body temperature elevated above the normal range. [from HPO]
A sudden sensation of feeling cold. [from HPO]
Pleuritic chest pain is characterized by sudden and intense sharp, stabbing, or burning pain in the chest when inhaling and exhaling. [from HPO]
An increase in the thickness of a structure. [from NCI]
Pain in muscle. [from HPO]

description: Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency. [from HPO]
An auscultated finding describing high or medium pitched and scratchy sound, generated by inflammation of the pericardial sac. (ACC-AHA) [from NCI]
Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale. [from HPO]

Very rapid breathing. [from HPO]

Pain in muscle. [from HPO]

Increased discharge of mucus from the nose. [from HPO]
Any kind of inflammatory process of the tonsils, pharynx, or/and larynx characterized by pain in swallowing. [from NCI]

Painful or difficult urination. [from HPO]
Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve. [from HPO]

description: Mental distress resulting from concern for something impending or anticipated. [from NCI]

The inability of an organ or organ system to maintain homeostasis due to functional overload, often caused by the presence of disease intrinsic to the organ or organ system, or dysfunction in other organ systems. [from NCI]
Written or spoken words that are excessively critical, insulting, and/or intimidating. [from PSY]

A neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by one or more of the following essential features: immobility, mutism, negativism (active or passive refusal to follow commands), mannerisms, stereotypies, posturing, grimacing, excitement, echolalia, echopraxia, muscular rigidity, and stupor; sometimes punctuated by sudden violent outbursts, panic, or hallucinations. This condition may be associated with psychiatric illnesses (e.g., SCHIZOPHRENIA; MOOD DISORDERS) or organic disorders (NEUROLEPTIC MALIGNANT SYNDROME; ENCEPHALITIS, etc.). (From DSM-IV, 4th ed, 1994; APA, Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms, 1994) [from MeSH]
